SENT.plain: To examine the role of antiplatelet drugs in the secondary prevention of arteriosclerotic arterial disease following carotid endarterectomy, a clinical series (n = 252) was analyzed
Based on these results a prospective randomized trial was initiated, comparing the effect of antiplatelet drugs (acetyl-salicylic acid [ASA] 1000 mg/day) versus untreated controls
In both investigations patient survival was the primary end point
A cardiac risk (n = 91) implied a significant reduction in patient survival (p less than 0.019 Breslow, p less than 0.052 Mantel)

Antiaggregating drugs prolonged survival in the collective series (p less than 0.0001 Breslow, p less than 0.0002 Mantel) and in the subgroup of patients with cardiac risk (p less than 0.014 Breslow, p less than 0.020 Mantel) as well
In the prospective trial 66 patients were recruited, receiving ASA (n = 32) versus no therapy (n = 34)
During follow-up 15 patients died, 4 in the treatment, and 11 in the control group
Between both groups there was a significant difference in the probability of survival (p less than 0.021 Breslow, p less than 0.048 Mantel)
